The answer for the best among them: not a pleasingly significant chance. So they all met up and decided to only produce bulbs that would last a short time. Literally this happened. Also we have 20 times more people employed in our economy and in the world's economy in the lighting appliance manufacturing sector. It is sad actually. They should turn it off and replace it with an LED bulb. The awful truth is that EVERY incandescent bulb can last basically forever. But lasting forever is not a good thing in this case. Imagine if you have a choice of a bright LED bulb that uses 10 watts, or a very dim old incandescent bulb that puts out 1/40th as much light yet uses 50 watts. Which is better? You would need 40 of these old bulbs to put out as much light, and it would take 2000 watts instead of 10 watts. Do the math. Now the secret: Want an incandescent bulb to last for the next 100 years? Here’s what you do: Install a 100 Watt incandescent bulb designed for 110V in your ceiling, and run a line from a transformer supplying 50V DC (notice how dim the photo of the old Edison bulb is). And you’ll pay thousands of dollars more in electricity over the next century than if you had bought an LED bulb instead.

The fact is that Edison was as much a promoter as an inventor. Until improvements in creating a vacuum inside incandescent light bulbs were developed, Edison’s early light bulbs had a life of less than an hour. So when he invited the press to witness his marvelous light bulb at the 1893 World Fair in Chicago, each member of the press was granted a private 20 minute audience. Between audiences, the leaky bulbs were replaced. The equivalent of early 19th century “fake news” was that Edison’s incandescent bulb burned for days on end. Meanwhile Edison had a small army of people at Menlo Park perfecting the light bulb that eventually made him a very rich man. He would lose his fortune trying to corner the iron ore market using ore mined in New Jersey, in the years immediately preceding the development of the Mesabi Range. I don’t mean throw shade on one of the greatest inventors of all time, but Thomas Edison had far more failures than successes. Aside from learning from his mistakes, Edison also new how to sell his ideas.

Any lamp, bulb or LED could last forever (at least till the owner is gone). They last as much as who make them want. If they last forever, nobody would buy often. The manufacturer can adjust the alloy , thickness, etc. to give it an approximate lifetime. What make a bulb light dead is mainly to switch it on. If you turn it on when the AC current is at peak (it goes from 0 to ~155Volts 120 times per second) you stress the filament and reduce its life. Since it happens randomly, the lifetime is estimated (still programmed).With LED lamps it is even easer to program the lifetime. Most of them have the drice circuit dead but the LED still works! They do it with everything. What most reduce lifetime is the fact of switch on! This happens with your car too. It’s motor could last 3 times more miles if you run continuously, like taxis (their motors last much more miles). Some computer servers have extended warranty is they are used always ON (based mainly on hard disks mechanical startup stress). If that Edison bulb was daily turned off, got cold and ON again, it probably would be dead many years ago!

I’ll add to the other excellent answers that point out that the bulb you are probably referring to is being run at a very low voltage and continuously, to avoid sudden surges of current you get when turn a light on, and is the point where most bulbs do eventually fail. Prior to 1924 light bulbs were made that lasted much longer than bulbs after 1924. The reason is that light bulb makers got together in 1924 and formed a cartel that mandated the standard 1,000 hour lifetime for bulbs (see The Great Lightbulb Conspiracy). And while the cartel has long since disbanded, we have lived with the results of that until CFL and LED bulbs with longer lifetimes became more prevalent.

is being run at a very low voltage (50v) and continuously, to avoid sudden surges of power draw you get when turn a light on(The Filament only moves when it is heating/cooling… it flexes and contracts), and is the point where most bulbs do eventually fail. Think about it… How often does a light just… wink out… vs. how often does a light “blow” riiight as you flip the switch in the room ON. Or, you go into a room where the light USED to be working fine, but this time, when you flip the switch… nothing (It fell apart as it cooled/contracted last time you turned it off)

Incandescent bulb design is a tradeoff between efficiency and lifetime. If you design the bulb to run cooler (equivalent to reducing the voltage) it will last much longer, but will be less efficient, so it will use more electricity for the same brightness, The additional cost of the electricity is much more than the cost of the bulb. You can buy “long-life” bulbs, rated for 2000 hours, or you can buy standard bulbs rated for 1000 hours. (At least you used to be able to) You will find that the 1000 hour bulbs are much brighter than the 2000 hour bulbs for a given wattage. Photographers used to use “photoflood” bulbs which were very white and very bright. But they only lasted 6 hours. You can also buy 130V bulbs, which are fairly dim on 120V, but last much longer.

Nearly every Reliability Engineer (I can’t verify this) will tell you that Everything Fails. Eventually. (Can’t really verify this, either, but I’ve never yet been proven wrong.) The physical life of components is typically quantified in either operating time or cycles. The life of electronics and electrical components especially depend more on the number of power cycles than on operating time. If the bulb is rarely powered on and off then, while it won’t last forever, it will last long enough for all practical purposes.
